The man was a tall, dark-haired individual, with a stern expression upon his face. The woman was shorter, with auburn hair, and her face was deathly pale. They were both standing perfectly still, their eyes fixed upon the coffin, and they seemed to be entirely unconscious of my presence. I watched them for a few moments, and then my eyes wandered to the coffin. It was a plain, black coffin, with a silver plate upon the lid, and a few flowers scattered over the top. I could not see the face of the deceased, but I could see that it was a woman. I wondered who she was, and what relation she bore to the two people in the aisle. As I sat there, a faint rustling sound came from the front of the church, and the clergyman rose to his feet. The two people in the aisle turned, and their eyes met those of the clergyman. He began to speak in a low, solemn tone, and the two people turned back to the coffin, their eyes fixed upon it once more. I listened to the clergyman's words, and I learned that the deceased was a young woman, who had died suddenly, and that the two people in the aisle were her husband and sister. As the clergyman finished speaking, the husband and sister turned, and walked slowly down the aisle, their eyes fixed upon the coffin. They passed by me, and went out of the church, leaving me alone with the clergyman. He turned to me, and spoke in a low tone, and I learned that the funeral was to be a quiet one, with no mourners present save the husband and sister of the deceased. I nodded, and he turned back to the altar, and began to pray. I sat in silence, my eyes fixed upon the coffin, and my mind filled with thoughts of the young woman who lay within it.

El taxi avanzaba lentamente a través de las calles desiertas, iluminadas solo por la luz de las farolas y la luna que se filtraba a través de las nubes. De repente, el vehículo se detuvo frente a una casa de aspecto sombrío y abandonado. Holmes se incorporó de inmediato y abrió la puerta del taxi, descendiendo a la cal con un movimiento rápido y sigiloso. Watson lo siguió, sintiendo que se adentraban en un mundo de misterio y peligro.

en_results_raw: for the longer they delayed, the greater the risk of detection. And so, one night, they made their move. It was a night much like any other, the moon hidden behind a veil of clouds, the streets empty and silent. But in the darkness, a sense of anticipation hung in the air, a feeling that something was about to unfold. And then, without warning, the sound of footsteps echoed through the stillness, the soft thud of feet on pavement, growing louder with each passing moment. It was a sound that seemed to come from nowhere, and yet, it was a sound that seemed to be heading somewhere, a sound that seemed to have a purpose. And as the footsteps drew closer, the sense of anticipation grew, until it seemed to be almost palpable, a living, breathing thing that pulsed with an energy all its own. And then, just as suddenly as they had begun, the footsteps stopped, leaving behind a silence that was even more profound than before. It was as if the very world was holding its breath, waiting to see what would happen next.

Pero, a pesar de sus esfuerzos, la joven parecía cada vez más enamorada de John, y su padrastro comenzó a temer que sus planes fueran a fracasar. Un día, decidió llamar a John a su presencia y le ofreció una gran suma de dinero para que se olvidara de la joven y se casara con otra. Pero John, que era un hombre de principios, se negó a aceptar el dinero y le dijo al padrastro que su amor por la joven era sincero y que no se dejaría comprar. El padrastro, enfurecido, le dijo que si no se casaba con otra, nunca heredaría el dinero de su hijastra. Pero John no se intimidó y siguió visitando a la joven en secreto, hasta que finalmente lograron casarse en contra la voluntad del padrastro. La joven heredó el dinero de su madre y vivieron felices para siempre, mientras que el padrastro se quedó solo y sin un centavo.

"I must say, Mr. Holmes," he began, "that I am still a little puzzled by your remarks about the disappearance of Lady Frances. You seemed to imply that there was something suspicious about it, and yet you have not told us what you mean." Holmes leaned back in his chair, steepling his fingers together, and regarding our visitor with a thoughtful gaze. "I did not mean to imply anything, Mr. Wilson," he said slowly, "but merely to point out that the circumstances of Lady Frances' disappearance are not quite so simple as they appear at first sight. There are one or two points which I have not yet had time to investigate, but which I hope to clear up before long." He paused, and then added, "I think I shall have to ask you a few more questions, Mr. Wilson, if you can spare the time." Our visitor nodded, and Holmes went on, "You said, I think, that you were in the garden when Lady Frances was last seen. Can you tell me exactly what you were doing there, and what you saw?"

en_first_half: “Away we went then, and we drove for at least an hour. Colonel Lysander Stark had said that it was only seven miles, but I should think, from the rate that we seemed to go, and from the time that we took, that it must have been nearer twelve. He sat at my side in silence all the time, and I was aware, more than once when I glanced in his direction, that he was looking at me with great intensity. The country roads seem to be not very good in that part of the world, for we lurched and jolted terribly. I tried to look out of the windows to see something of where we were, but they were made of frosted glass, and I could make out nothing save the occasional bright blur
en_second_half: of a passing light. Now and then I hazarded some remark to break the monotony of the journey, but the colonel answered only in monosyllables, and the conversation soon flagged. At last, however, the bumping of the road was exchanged for the crisp smoothness of a gravel-drive, and the carriage came to a stand. Colonel Lysander Stark sprang out, and, as I followed after him, pulled me swiftly into a porch which gaped in front of us. We stepped, as it were, right out of the carriage and into the hall, so that I failed to catch the most fleeting glance of the front of the house. The instant that I had crossed the threshold the door slammed heavily behind us, and I heard faintly the rattle of the wheels as the carriage drove away.
en_results: of a light, which I took to be a house or a cottage, and the dark shape of trees and bushes. The air was thick with the scent of blooming flowers and fresh cut grass, and I felt a sense of peace settle over me, despite the jolting of the carriage. She did not smile, but there was something in her face which made me think that she was not displeased to see us. The colonel went on to say that he was afraid we had been kept waiting, and that he hoped we were not too much fatigued by our journey. He led the way to the room he had spoken of, and we followed him, Miss Emily going last, with the lamp. The room was large and lofty, with a fire burning brightly in the grate, and a lamp or two upon the table. The colonel rang the bell, and a servant came in, to whom he gave some orders about supper. Then he turned to us and said, "I hope you will do me the pleasure of taking pot-luck with me. I am afraid it will not be a very sumptuous meal, but I hope you will not be too much disappointed." I said that we were much obliged to him, and that we would be very glad to take pot-luck with him. Miss Emily had put the lamp down upon the table, and was standing by the fire, looking at us with an air of quiet curiosity. I thought that she seemed a little shy, but not ill at ease. The servant came in again, with a tray, and the colonel said, "Let us have supper at once. I am sure you must be hungry after your journey." We sat down to the table, and the colonel took his place at the head. Miss Emily sat on his right hand, and we on the opposite side. The servant handed the dishes, and we began our meal. en_results_raw: “It is fortunate, for you will perhaps be able to post me up. I read nothing except the criminal news and the agony column. I am particularly interested in the latter, as it is so much more amusing than the former. The criminal news is always the same - a dull repetition of the same old crimes, committed by the same old people, in the same old way. But the agony column is always fresh and exciting, full of new and interesting problems, and the most ingenious and varied solutions. I never tire of reading it, and I am always eager to see what new and thrilling developments it will bring. And I must say, I am not disappointed. The agony column is always up to its usual high standard, and I am never bored. I am always on the edge of my seat, wondering what will happen next, and how the various problems will be solved. It is a never-ending source of entertainment, and I am grateful to the editor for providing it. I only wish that the criminal news could be made half as interesting, but I suppose that is too much to hope for. Still, I shall continue to read both, and enjoy them in my own way.”
